title: Hand-Wash or Machine-Wash Your On Cloud Running Shoes

steps.title: Soak the laces and insoles in water and laundry detergent for an hour.
steps.content: Soak the laces and insoles in water and laundry detergent for an hour. Remove the laces and insoles from your On Cloud shoes. Fill a small bowl with warm water and add a scoop of powder or 1 tablespoon (0.52 oz) of liquid laundry detergent. Place the laces and insoles in the bowl. Leave them to soak for about 1 hour. [1] X Research source Alternatively, fill a bowl with ⅔ cup (5.63 oz) of baking soda, ½ cup (4.22 oz) of liquid soap, ½ cup (4.22 oz) of warm water, and 2 tablespoons (1.04 oz) of white vinegar. Allow the laces and insoles to soak inside for 1 hour. Gently wash your laces and insoles using a bar of laundry soap or place them in a mesh bag and throw it into a washing machine on a delicate cycle with cold water.

steps.title: Remove any excess dirt from the shoes with a soft brush.
steps.content: Remove any excess dirt from the shoes with a soft brush. Over a garbage can, tap the shoe soles together to knock off any dirt or debris. Using a dry soft shoe cleaning brush or an old toothbrush, gently scrub off dirt on the outsole. [2] X Research source If the dirt on your shoes is wet, wait for your shoes to dry completely before tapping the soles together.

steps.title: Wash the shoes using warm water and mild laundry detergent.
steps.content: Wash the shoes using warm water and mild laundry detergent. Fill a bucket or a sink with warm water. Add in a scoop of powder or 1 tablespoon (0.52 oz) of liquid laundry detergent. Place the shoes in the water and use a soft cloth or sponge to gently clean them. Wipe the shoes with a soft cloth dampened in water to remove any remaining detergent when you're done. To get rid of stubborn stains, spray carpet cleaner or an all-purpose cleaner on any stains on the fabric parts of the shoe. Wait 5 minutes, then blot the stains with a damp cloth or sponge. Alternatively, dip a soft brush in a small bowl of warm water and 1 tablespoon (0.52 oz) of laundry detergent and scrub stains in a small, circular motion.

steps.title: Clean the outsoles using a baking soda paste and a soft brush.
steps.content: Clean the outsoles using a baking soda paste and a soft brush. If the outsoles aren’t completely clean after the laundry detergent bath, create a paste using ¼ cup (2.11 oz) of baking soda and 1 tablespoon (0.52 oz) of water. Apply the paste to the rubber outsoles and scrub any stains with a soft brush or old toothbrush. [3] X Research source Dip a cloth in clean water and wipe the outsoles with it to remove any gunk and paste. If the toothbrush hairs are too soft to scrub, cut the hairs using a pair of scissors to make them short and strong. For extra stain-scrubbing power, make a cleaning paste using 2 tablespoons (1.04 oz) of baking soda, 2 tablespoons (1.04 oz) of laundry booster , 1 teaspoon (0.17 oz) of hydrogen peroxide , and 1 tablespoon (0.52 oz) of water. Alternatively, slightly wet a Magic Eraser with water and scrub at any stains or scuff marks on the rubber edges and the bottom of the shoe. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Place a ball of paper inside each shoe and allow them to air dry.
steps.content: Place a ball of paper inside each shoe and allow them to air dry. Roll a paper towel, a piece of paper, or a newspaper page into a ball large enough to fill the inside of the shoe. Place 2 balls inside each shoe to absorb any leftover moisture. [5] X Research source Leave your shoes in a room temperature location to dry for at least 1 hour. Avoid placing your shoes on direct heat sources like radiators. The intensity of the heat might cause the materials in your shoe to warp or lose their shape. Once the laces, insoles, and shoes are completely dry, reassemble your shoes and store them in a warm, dry place out of direct sunlight.

steps.title: Remove any loose dirt from your shoes using a soft brush.
steps.content: Remove any loose dirt from your shoes using a soft brush. Remove the insoles and laces from your shoes. Tap the soles of your shoes together over a garbage can to knock off any large chunks of dirt and debris. Wet a soft brush or old toothbrush with water and scrub off any dirt on the outside of each shoe. [6] X Research source Machine washing is generally not recommended for specialized running shoes because it may shorten their lifespan. [7] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source

steps.title: Spray stains with a carpet cleaner or an all-purpose cleaner.
steps.content: Spray stains with a carpet cleaner or an all-purpose cleaner. Spray any dirt, grass, blood, or oil stains with a spot carpet cleaner like Resolve or OxiClean stain remover or with a water-based all-purpose cleaner. [8] X Research source Alternatively, scrub with a soft brush and a paste made of 2 tablespoons (1.04 oz) of baking soda, 2 tablespoons (1.04 oz) of laundry booster, 1 teaspoon (0.17 oz) of hydrogen peroxide, and 1 tablespoon (0.52 oz) of water.

steps.title: Add 2 to 4 towels to the inside of the washing machine.
steps.content: Add 2 to 4 towels to the inside of the washing machine. The speed of the washing machine can cause your On Cloud running shoes to bang against the sides of the drum. Add at least 2 towels to the washing machine to prevent damage to your shoes or the drum. This can also help muffle any noise from the shoes being washed. [9] X Research source Alternatively, put half a load of your regular laundry in the washing machine.

steps.title: Place the shoes, laces, and insoles in a mesh bag inside the machine.
steps.content: Place the shoes, laces, and insoles in a mesh bag inside the machine. Unlace your shoes and take out the insoles. Place the laces, insoles, and shoes inside a mesh bag or an old pillowcase. [10] X Research source Place the mesh bag inside the washing machine on top of the old towels. If you use an old pillowcase, choose one with a zipper, secure the opening with a rubber band, or knot the fabric loosely to make sure the shoes, laces, and insoles don’t fall out. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Add laundry detergent and wash on delicate with cold water.
steps.content: Add laundry detergent and wash on delicate with cold water. Delicate cycles have slower spin cycles that can help reduce noise and damage to your shoes or washing machine. Add liquid detergent to the dispenser. Select the delicate cycle, choose the coldest temperature available for the wash, and start the machine . [12] X Research source If your shoes are completely white, add ¼ cup (2.11 oz) of bleach to the dispenser before washing. [13] X Research source Liquid detergent may be better than powder detergent for this task because powder doesn’t always dissolve fully in cold water. [14] X Research source Although some people believe that heat can kill off odor-producing bacteria , most modern laundry detergents contain enzymes that remove odors without hot water. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Put a ball of paper in each shoe and allow them to air dry completely.
steps.content: Put a ball of paper in each shoe and allow them to air dry completely. Take the mesh bag out of the washing machine. Gently wring out your shoes, insoles, and laces to remove any excess water. Roll up 2 balls of newspaper, paper towels, or paper and place 1 in each shoe. [16] X Research source Allow the laces, insoles, and shoes to dry completely, then reassemble your shoes. Don't put your shoes in the dryer, which can ruin them. When you’re not using them, store your shoes in a warm, dry place out of direct sunlight. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Dust off and scrub your shoes with a soft brush and water after each use.
steps.content: Dust off and scrub your shoes with a soft brush and water after each use. To quickly clean your running shoes , tap the soles of your shoes together over a trash can to knock off any loose dirt. Wet a soft brush or old toothbrush with water and scrub off any dirt or mud buildup. Store the shoes in a dry place and let them air dry. [18] X Research source If you’d like, soak the laces and insoles in warm water and a scoop of laundry detergent for an hour. Rinse them off with clean water, squeeze out the excess moisture, then let them air dry alongside the shoes. Allow the shoes, laces, and insoles to dry completely before reassembling your shoes.
